image.altText: A composite image of muddy flooded machinery, a large sinkhole, and a metal pipe with gas coming out of it.

items.synopsis: Snowy Hydro's tunnelling machine caused a sinkhole and spent months barely moving, then the troubled project's tunnel began filling with gas.

title.children: 'You've screwed up, haven't you?': The $2 billion mistake behind Snowy 2.0

image.altText: Euros and Swiss francs

items.synopsis: Australians hold more than a third of a trillion dollars in known tax havens and profit-shifting by multinational firms deprives Treasury of almost $11 billion a year, finds a new international report.

title.children: There are billions of reasons to fix tax evasion. Experts say saving democracy is one of them

image.altText: A man carries a young girl wearing pink pyjamas with a worried and urgent expression on his face

items.synopsis: If we do not understand the pain and misery on both sides of this war, then we cannot begin to think of how to help stop the never-ending cycle of pain and misery in Gaza, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Gaza is the most miserable place on Earth and in Israel, fear is everywhere. This tragedy cannot go on

image.altText: People wearing various uniforms, one saying UN, standing in front of a truck with boxes on board

items.synopsis: A second convoy of aid trucks enters Gaza as Israel apologises for accidentally firing at Egyptian border guards.

title.children: 14 trucks carrying aid enter Gaza as Israeli tank accidentally hits Egyptian border guards

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Gaza's most crowded United Nations relief shelter is currently sheltering around 21,000 people, according to the UN's latest update. The number of (displaced people) per shelter has reached in many shelters 4,400," the update says, adding the buildings were "designed to host 1,500-2,000". It also notes "entire neighbourhoods" have been destroyed in the Gaza Strip since October 7. "The Gaza Ministry of Public Works reported the destruction of 15,749 housing units and the rendering of 10,935 housing units uninhabitable, as of 21 October," it says. "Another 142,500 housing units sustained minor to moderate damage. " The total number of housing units destroyed or damaged accounts for at least 43 per cent of all housing units in the Gaza Strip."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 43 per cent of Gaza's homes destroyed as thousands search for shelter

children.content: Gaza's most crowded United Nations relief shelter is currently sheltering around 21,000 people, according to the UN's latest update.
The number of (displaced people) per shelter has reached in many shelters 4,400," the update says, adding the buildings were "designed to host 1,500-2,000".

props.alt: A graph showing the number of destroyed buildings split into lightly damaged, severely damaged and uninhabitable, and destroyed

children.content: (United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs)
It also notes "entire neighbourhoods" have been destroyed in the Gaza Strip since October 7.
"The Gaza Ministry of Public Works reported the destruction of 15,749 housing units and the rendering of 10,935 housing units uninhabitable, as of 21 October," it says.
"Another 142,500 housing units sustained minor to moderate damage.
" The total number of housing units destroyed or damaged accounts for at least 43 per cent of all housing units in the Gaza Strip."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The 14 trucks that entered Gaza today account for "about 3 per cent of the daily average volume " of supplies the area received before fresh hostilities flared, according to the United Nations. The aid marks "another glimmer of hope", the organisation said in its latest update, but called for fuel supplies to be allowed in "immediately". "Aid deliveries entering Gaza have not included fuel," the report said. "UNRWA, by far the largest humanitarian provider in Gaza, will exhaust its fuel reserves within the next three days."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN says latest trucks 'about 3 per cent' of Gaza's pre-war daily supplies

children.content: The 14 trucks that entered Gaza today account for "about
3 per cent of the daily average volume
" of supplies the area received before fresh hostilities flared, according to the United Nations.
The aid marks "another glimmer of hope",
the organisation said in its latest update, but called for fuel supplies to be allowed in "immediately".
"Aid deliveries entering Gaza have not included fuel," the report said.
"UNRWA, by far the largest humanitarian provider in Gaza, will exhaust its fuel reserves within the next three days."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Trucks carrying vital aid have arrived in Gaza with more waiting at the Rafah border crossing with Egypt. But that aid will be a "drop in the ocean" and won't help as it should if Israeli bombs continue to pound the Gaza Strip, CEO of the Egyptian Food Bank Mohsen Sarhan has warned. Speaking to Radio National's David Lipson, Mr Sarhan said whatever aid was coming into Gaza now was just "window dressing". "We're having a grave situation in Gaza now — doctors (have) started doing surgeries without anaesthetics and without antibiotics … people are being tortured to have surgeries without anaesthetics — it's a very bad situation," he said. "People there are dying by the hundreds every day and the death has reached a level that they can't even bring their dead out from the rubble … they don't have equipment to get the dead out. They don't even have body bags to bury them, it's turning into an open graveyard." He said aid agencies were angry and frustrated at how long it was taking to help the people of Gaza, with many unable to operate safely. "The killing has to stop … if the ceasefire happens and the killing stops, aid will have a meaning, but right now it's a complete mess there. We have the money and we have the supplies but the bombing doesn't stop."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Food bank CEO warns Gaza turning into an 'open graveyard' as aid trickles in

featuredLink.title: Gaza: First aid convoys arrive as humanitarian crisis intensifies - ABC listen

children.content: Trucks carrying vital aid have arrived in Gaza with more waiting at the Rafah border crossing with Egypt.
But that aid will be a "drop in the ocean" and won't help as it should if Israeli bombs continue to pound the Gaza Strip, CEO of the Egyptian Food Bank Mohsen Sarhan has warned.

props.alt: A man wearing a suit stands in front of a truck.

children.content: CEO of the Egyptian Food Bank Mohsen Sarhan warns aid is not enough.
Speaking to Radio National's David Lipson, Mr Sarhan said whatever aid was coming into Gaza now was just "window dressing".

"We're having a grave situation in Gaza now — doctors (have) started doing surgeries without anaesthetics and without antibiotics … people are being tortured to have surgeries without anaesthetics — it's a very bad situation," he said.

"People there are dying by the hundreds every day and the death has reached a level that they can't even bring their dead out from the rubble … they don't have equipment to get the dead out. They don't even have body bags to bury them, it's turning into an open graveyard."
He said aid agencies were angry and frustrated at how long it was taking to help the people of Gaza, with many unable to operate safely.

"The killing has to stop … if the ceasefire happens and the killing stops, aid will have a meaning, but right now it's a complete mess there. We have the money and we have the supplies but the bombing doesn't stop."

image.altText: A red R-F-S fire truck in front of burning trees.

items.synopsis: Residents around Glens Creek Road and Frickers Road at Nymboida are being advised to prepare now after a bushfire burning in the area returned to the Emergency warning level.

title.children: Up to 30 NSW North Coast properties under threat as bushfire warning intensifies

image.altText: An aerial view of a house and outbuildings on a green patch, surrounded by burnt bushland.

items.synopsis: As the climate changes, an increasing number of houses in Australia are projected to be exposed to bushfires. Now, a new tool, flagged by a royal commission, has been developed that lets individuals and communities realise their vulnerabilities, plan for change and go into the next disaster better prepared.

title.children: 'I wish I'd made my house resilient for far less money': How to build a house that can survive extreme weather

image.altText: A man wearing a rainbow lanyard sits at a desk, glancing down.

items.synopsis: A "Hotties List" of graduate women in the Infrastructure Department was reportedly circulated by male graduates, according to a complaint by one employee.

title.children: Junior women reportedly ranked in 'Hotties List' circulated by Infrastructure Department staff

image.altText: Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift artwork

items.synopsis: Taylor Swift continues to dominate coverage as she supports Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs — here's what the melding of two of America's biggest pop culture phenomena mean for both Swifties and the NFL.

title.children: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce is a phenomenon that is not going away — here's what it means for the NFL

image.altText: A man with a bald head and beard wears a black jacket and sits against a black background

items.synopsis: As a child Scott Wynands was "very hot tempered" and inquisitive — once putting a sandwich in a VHS player — but being diagnosed with ADHD at 43 helped him make sense of his life's trajectory.

title.children: Scott 'lost lots of jobs' because of ADHD. He wants others to know what the condition is like

image.altText: Joe Biden and Anthony Albanese laughing while walking through a door

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese is going to the US at the invitation of Joe Biden, but the drama on Capitol Hill means his message might not be heard as loudly as he'd have liked, writes Jade Macmillan.

title.children: Albanese is finally getting his US visit, but America's wild dysfunction complicates the trip

image.altText: Bottles of wine

items.synopsis: Wine exports to China have dropped to a low of $10 million a year, but China's announcement it will review tariffs on imports has given a glimmer of hope to the industry.

title.children: China wine tariff review 'no silver bullet', but Australian producers hold hope for the future

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Israel-Gaza war helped send US 10-year bond rates within a whisker of 5 per cent on Friday, leaving Wall Street in the red every session last week, with the ASX again following. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX continues slide as Israel-Gaza war worries see bond interest rates push higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It feels like it was only a few weeks ago we were in the middle of reporting season, but now we're well and truly in the swing of AGM season. (Truly, where does the time go?) If you're a frequent markets watcher, you'll know there's plenty of meetings that take place between now and the end of the year. But if you're new to the world of AGMs (welcome!) we've got you covered. The crux of it is Australia's biggest companies are holding a big annual meeting with their shareholders, where they discuss their previous year's financial results, answer questions, and elect board members. There's already been a few AGMs in the past week or so, but there's plenty more coming up. — so make things easier, here's a handy table I prepared earlier. Feel free to search for specific companies by name, ASX code, or meeting date to pop in your diary. (Also: please note these meeting dates can be subject to change, and some meetings have already passed — so click through to get to the most recent dates.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: It's AGM season — here's a list of all the meetings coming up

children.content: It feels like it was only a few weeks ago we were in the middle of reporting season, but now we're well and truly in the swing of AGM season. (Truly, where does the time go?)
If you're a frequent markets watcher, you'll know there's plenty of meetings that take place between now and the end of the year.

But if you're new to the world of AGMs (welcome!) we've got you covered. The crux of it is Australia's biggest companies are holding a big annual meeting with their shareholders, where they discuss their previous year's financial results, answer questions, and elect board members.
There's already been a few AGMs in the past week or so, but there's plenty more coming up. — so make things easier, here's a handy table I prepared earlier.
Feel free to search for specific companies by name, ASX code, or meeting date to pop in your diary.
(Also: please note these meeting dates can be subject to change,
and some meetings have already passed — so click through to get to the most recent dates.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 remains down on concerns about the Israel-Gaza war, inflation and interest rates, off around 0.8% to 6,843 points by 12:30pm AEDT. But one stock defying the recent gloom is Weebit Nano, which develops "advanced semiconductor memory technology". It's the ASX 200's top gainer by far today up 16.2% to $4.37, and has gained around 50% over the past four trading sessions. It all began with a 6.9% jump to $3.11 on Wednesday, a day before it put out a market update pre-open on Thursday morning announcing a major deal for South Korean foundry DB HiTek to licence its technology on chips. It then rose a further 6.8% on Thursday and 13.3% on Friday. Based in Israel and France, the company had previously updated the market on October 10 to assure investors that its operations would be unaffected by the Israel-Gaza war, with its lab currently unaffected and work-from-home contingency plans in place for its Israeli staff if needed. The other biggest gains as of the middle of the trading day are: ARB Corporation +4% to $31.46 Insignia Financial +2.7% to $2.095 Resmed +2.4% to $23.18 Fisher and Paykel Healthcare +1.9% to $19.29 The biggest losers (amongst many) are: New Hope Corporation -9% to $5.89 Pilbara Minerals -5.2% to $3.66 Mineral Resources -4.1% to $57.13 Alumina Ltd -4% to $0.7775 Coronado Global Resources -3.9% to $1.62 Overall, only a quarter of the ASX 200 companies were gaining ground, with 144 in the red and six flat. Healthcare (+1%) and consumer non-cyclicals (+0.4%) were the only sectors in the black. Energy (-2.4%) was down sharply, led by coal miners, while mining (-1.9%) and education (-1%) were also off steeply.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Weebit Nano (again) surges as ASX slides

, which develops "advanced semiconductor memory technology".

Based in Israel and France, the company had previously updated the market on October 10 to assure investors that its operations would be unaffected by the Israel-Gaza war, with its lab currently unaffected and work-from-home contingency plans in place for its Israeli staff if needed.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The September quarter Consumer Price Index (CPI) from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) is going to be critical for the Reserve Bank's decision on whether it needs to raise interest rates at least once more, possibly as soon as November 7. So what are economists expecting to see at 11:30am AEDT this Wednesday when the ABS publishes CPI data for both the month and quarter of September? Westpac, which publishes a very detailed category-by-category breakdown of its forecast, is tipping both headline and 'trimmed mean' figures to come in at 1.1% for the quarter and 5.3 and 5% for the year, respectively. ( Trimmed mean is a key "underlying" measure of inflation preferred by the Reserve Bank because it excludes the most volatile price moves up and down). Westpac senior economist Justin Smirk says there are big uncertainties about just how much temporary electricity bill rebates and permanently increased childcare subsidies will offset price rises in those sectors, making forecasting harder than usual. " Auto fuel is making the most significant contribution in the September quarter (+0.26ppt), closely followed by utilities (0.24ppt), food (0.17ppt), rents (0.13ppt), financial services (0.10ppt) and then dwelling purchases (0.09ppt)." CBA's forecast for inflation is a little lower, at 0.9 and 1% for the headline and trimmed mean, respectively. It believes such a result would see the RBA sit tight in November. "Our forecast for Q3 23 CPI is broadly similar to the RBA's implied profile from August. We believe this is consistent with monetary policy on hold in November." However, the bank's economists warn that the risks are to the upside for inflation, and a result much higher than forecast could see the RBA hike the cash rate by 0.25%pt next month. UBS's George Tharenou is forecasting an even higher 1.2%/1.1% headline/underlying result, which would add to pressure for a rate rise. ANZ's economists see the result as being 1.1/1.2% for headline and trimmed mean, which they say could see another rate hike. "This outcome, particularly for trimmed mean, would cause the RBA some discomfort given its 'low tolerance for a slower return of inflation to target' than current forecasts. "As we noted after the most recent minutes, risks of RBA action in the near-term appear to be rising. For now, we expect the cash rate to remain at 4.1%, although we'll ultimately make a call on the November Board meeting in the wake of the CPI." For what it's worth, the typical forecast according to a survey of economists by Reuters is for both headline and trimmed mean inflation to rise 1.1% in the quarter, or 5.3% and 5% up respectively over the past year. Financial markets are currently pricing in about a 30% chance of the RBA lifting the cash rate in a fortnight's time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What are we likely to see in the inflation numbers out on Wednesday?

image.altText: A man and woman stand in doorway with their young daughter and baby is held in the arms of her mother

items.synopsis: Kylie Moore-Gilbert spent 804 days in an Iranian prison accused of being a spy. Sami Shah has been twice divorced. The pair never thought they’d find love again. Then they went on a dating app.

title.children: 'Are you a spy or something?': When Sami Shah swiped right, he never believed he would be dating a former hostage

image.altText: Kitchen worker uses tongs in a pub kitchen in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank is deadly serious about maintaining the welfare of all Australians, but it's also deadly serious about anchoring inflation and it won't stop until that's achieved, writes David Taylor.

title.children: We'll soon have the next piece of the puzzle on inflation — and it'll impact whether interest rates go up

image.altText: A man wearing a suit looks serious.

items.synopsis: Cleveland Dodd died after being found unresponsive in his cell at Casuarina Prison's Unit 18, and WA Premier Roger Cook says the 16-year-old youth detainee was "let down" by his government.

title.children: Premier refuses to rule out changes at top of Department of Justice after Unit 18 boy's death

image.altText: Two children.

items.synopsis: The aunt and uncle of two children who died and two others who were severely injured in a shed fire in Geelong say their mother tried to save them as she pulled them from the flames.

title.children: Geelong family reeling after shed fire kills two young children and injures siblings

image.altText: A man with brown hair smiling, he is wearing a blue hat and grey shirt and is in the woods.

items.synopsis: Benn Schinkel, 31, was in the Capricornia Correctional Centre over a dangerous driving charge when he was found with serious injuries that he later died from.

title.children: Parents plead for answers over alleged murder of son almost eligible for parole in Queensland prison

image.altText: Road closed sign on the side of road with crashed truck and car behind it in the bush

items.synopsis: Northern Territory Police have confirmed a man and woman, both aged 34, and four girls aged nine, six, four, and two were killed in the crash near Pine Creek last month.

title.children: Police confirm ages of family killed in Pine Creek crash, including four children

image.altText: The sign out of the front of the building and the crest, with an autumnal tree nearby and a blue sky beyond.

items.synopsis: The woman first complained to police early this month but officers only located the man when a neighbour reported hearing noises coming from their backyard and roof.

title.children: Canberra man who allegedly raped, choked and filmed his partner found hiding in roof cavity

image.altText: A hand holds up a glass of sparkling white wine in the sun

items.synopsis: Farmers groups say a proposed trade deal with the European Union would send some commodities backwards and is a bad deal for "every sector of Australian agriculture".

title.children: Farmers call on government to walk away from 'dud' EU trade deal

image.altText: Kaylee McKeown laughs with a crown on her head.

items.synopsis: Kaylee McKeown has won her third backstroke title in consecutive days in Budapest to seal the World Cup series crown and a $158,000 jackpot.

title.children: Backstroke queen Kaylee McKeown completes lucrative World Cup hat-trick

image.altText: A woman reclines in a chair.

items.synopsis: Among the millions of Australians facing food insecurity is Vanessa, who went from three part-time jobs to having very little income — but hunger relief charity Foodbank says the problem is increasingly impacting "mid-to-high-income earners".

title.children: 'Real shift' in food insecurity with more 'mid-to-high-income earners' experiencing it for first time

image.altText: Street view down to the Port of Portland

items.synopsis: Mayor Scott Martin denies the council has become "unworkable" after a string of resignations this year.

title.children: Glenelg Shire loses third councillor within months as Mayor concedes there are 'issues'

image.altText: An image from the air shot from behind a wind turbine, looking over paddocks and a number of other turbines.

items.synopsis: Consumers are being warned not to expect any immediate relief despite a big fall in wholesale power prices to their lowest levels in two years.

title.children: Wholesale power market tumbles but households warned not to expect price relief

image.altText: An Israeli soldier adjusts his rifle as he stands on a tank near Israel's border with Lebanon.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warns Hezbollah it will make "the mistake of its life" if it starts a war with Israel at the Lebanon border, as strikes on Gaza intensify for a looming ground invasion.

title.children: 'Mistake of its life': Israeli PM issues warning to Hezbollah as regional clashes intensify

image.altText: CCTV footage shows a girl being pulled unconscious from the metro train.

items.synopsis: Photos of the 16-year-old girl published on social media showed her unconscious with a respiratory tube and bandage over her head, visibly on life support.

title.children: Teenage girl allegedly beaten by Iran's morality police now 'brain dead', says state media

image.altText: woman behind the steering wheel in a car

items.synopsis: Moreton Bay has 94 suburbs, takes nearly an hour to traverse and is expecting 240 new residents a week for the next 25 years. But those who live here fear they're not prepared to cope with the impending population explosion.

title.children: This council is expecting 240 new residents a week for the next 25 years — and that has some concerned

image.altText: The Australian wheelchair rugby team gather on court for a celebratory group shot, holding the trophy after a tournament win.

items.synopsis: The Australian Steelers team tunes up for next year's Paralympics with a dominant display in the final to beat Canada and clinch the International Wheelchair Rugby World Cup title in Paris.

title.children: Aussie Steelers beat Canada to win wheelchair rugby World Cup in Paris

image.altText: A black and white photo of a woman.

items.synopsis: Detectives say a mystery photo found in the case file of an unknown woman found dead in 1966 at Sorrento could be the missing piece of the puzzle.

title.children: Photo clue in 57-year-old Victorian cold case mystery

image.altText: India and New Zealand players stand in the fog

items.synopsis: Heavy fog stopped play for a brief period in Dharamsala, but it could only delay India's march to victory against New Zealand, with Virat Kohli scoring 95.

title.children: India beat New Zealand — and the Himalayan fog — to remain perfect at the Cricket World Cup

image.altText: A blue F1 car drives past the finish line, with a chequered flag being waved.

items.synopsis: Oscar Piastri fails to finish the US Grand Prix, retiring after a blistering start where he gained four places on the opening lap.

title.children: Verstappen wins captivating US Grand Prix, Piastri retires early

image.altText: A footballer attempts to guide the ball into the net as a goalkeeper lunges to stop it.

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr sets up two goals in a dominant Chelsea performance, while Steph Catley and Caitlin Foord also win with Arsenal.

title.children: Kerr stars again for Chelsea as Matildas guns all notch wins in Women's Super League

image.altText: Man sitting on edge of pool, woman underwater wearing scuba gear

items.synopsis: Damian Jamieson moves carefully to avoid aggravating a back injury sustained in a workplace accident. But when he's fully submerged underwater, exercise physiologists have a hard time stopping him.

title.children: Damian's lived with constant pain for years, but now he's seeing results with immersion therapy
